quiz.title: Grade 12 Physics
quiz.subtitle: Unit 5, Quiz 3: Motion of Charged Particles in Magnetic Fields
quiz.subject: Physics

questions.question: If a charged particle enters a uniform magnetic field exactly perpendicular ($90^\circ$) to the field lines, what is the shape of its trajectory?
questions.explanation: With $\vec{v} \perp \vec{B}$, the magnetic force $F = qvB$ is constant in magnitude and always perpendicular to velocity, providing the centripetal force for uniform circular motion.

questions.question: The radius of curvature ($r$) of a charged particle in a magnetic field is directly proportional to which of the following?
questions.explanation: From $qvB = \frac{mv^2}{r}$, we get $r = \frac{mv}{qB}$. Thus $r \propto mv$ (momentum) when $q$ and $B$ are constant.

questions.question: A particle enters a magnetic field at an angle of $30^\circ$. What type of path will it follow?
options: It will come to a stop
questions.explanation: The velocity has components both parallel ($v_{\parallel} = v\cos30^\circ$) and perpendicular ($v_{\perp} = v\sin30^\circ$) to $\vec{B}$. The perpendicular component causes circular motion, while the parallel component causes linear translation along the field, resulting in helical motion.

questions.question: What happens to the kinetic energy of a proton as it moves through a uniform magnetic field?
options: It decreases as the particle curves.
It oscillates between maximum and minimum.
questions.explanation: Magnetic force $\vec{F} = q\vec{v} \times \vec{B}$ is always perpendicular to velocity, so $\vec{F} \cdot \vec{v} = 0$. No work is done, and by the work-energy theorem, kinetic energy remains constant.

questions.question: If the strength of the magnetic field is doubled, what happens to the radius of the particle's circular path?
questions.explanation: From $r = \frac{mv}{qB}$, radius is inversely proportional to $B$. Doubling $B$ halves the radius: $r' = \frac{mv}{q(2B)} = \frac{1}{2}r$.

questions.question: The time taken for a particle to complete one full revolution in a magnetic field (the cyclotron period) is independent of:
questions.explanation: Period $T = \frac{2\pi m}{qB}$ depends on $m$, $q$, and $B$, but not on $v$. As $v$ increases, the radius increases proportionally, keeping the period constant. This is the principle behind cyclotrons.

questions.question: A "Bubble Chamber" uses the trajectories of particles in a magnetic field to identify them. If two particles have the same $v$ and $B$, but curve in opposite directions, they must have:
questions.explanation: Force direction is given by $\vec{F} = q\vec{v} \times \vec{B}$. For the same $\vec{v}$ and $\vec{B}$, opposite curvatures indicate opposite signs of $q$, since the cross product changes direction with charge sign.

questions.question: In a cyclotron, what is the primary purpose of the magnetic field?
options: To increase the speed of the particles.
To keep the particles moving in a circular path.
To provide the potential difference for acceleration.
questions.explanation: The magnetic field provides the centripetal force to keep particles in circular orbits, while the alternating electric field between the dees accelerates them each time they cross the gap.

questions.question: Which component of velocity is responsible for the "pitch" (distance between loops) of a helical path?
questions.explanation: Pitch $p = v_{\parallel} \times T$, where $v_{\parallel}$ is the velocity component parallel to $\vec{B}$ and $T$ is the cyclotron period. This is the distance advanced along the field per revolution.

questions.question: If a particle's mass is doubled but all other factors remain constant, the frequency of its circular motion (cyclotron frequency) will:
questions.explanation: Cyclotron frequency $f = \frac{qB}{2\pi m}$ is inversely proportional to mass. Doubling mass halves the frequency: $f' = \frac{qB}{2\pi (2m)} = \frac{1}{2}f$.

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! You have mastered the motion of charged particles in magnetic fields, including circular/helical paths, radius/period relationships, and applications like cyclotrons.
scoreMessages.70: Very good! Solid understanding of particle trajectories. Review the independence of cyclotron period from velocity and how velocity components affect helical motion.
scoreMessages.50: Fair. Focus on: 1) The radius formula $r = mv/qB$, 2) Why kinetic energy is conserved, 3) How the period $T = 2\pi m/qB$ is velocity-independent, 4) Helical motion from velocity components.
scoreMessages.0: Start with the fundamentals: Review how magnetic forces cause circular motion, derive the radius and period formulas, and understand how velocity relative to the field direction determines the path shape.
